The Foundation whereof was laid in a Sermon preached at Knath in the County of Lincoln, at the Å¿olemn Interment of the Corps of the Right honourable and truly religious Lady Elizabeth, Wife of the Right Honourable Francis Lord Willughby, Baron of Parham.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONORABLE FRANCIS LORD WILLUGHBY, Baron of Parham.
div.p:
IT is uÅ¿ual for thoÅ¿e that appear in publick, to prefix Å¿ome great name before them, that they may gain the greater EÅ¿teem, and that the army of their words may be looked on to be more conÅ¿iderable, when they have Å¿o valiant a forlorn: It is no more then needs
that Å¿ome Coats have Å¿upporters, eÅ¿pecially when there are notes of abatement in the charge; AmongÅ¿t whom I rank my Å¿elf, who had I not had a copious Å¿ubject, Å¿hould have deÅ¿ired invention; who now only deÅ¿ire that my labour may find protection under your wing; and the more confident I am, that I Å¿hall not be fruÅ¿trated, when I conÅ¿ider who it is that is here preÅ¿ented to your LordÅ¿hips view.

I confeÅ¿s a fair front may be Å¿et before a mean Cottage by an unskilfull Builder; and I may rank your honourable Name as a Patron to that, which for its own merits Å¿ake is not worth your LordÅ¿hips reading, much leÅ¿s your protection: But I Å¿hall not Å¿o much deÅ¿ire that the faÅ¿hion of this monument be obÅ¿erved by you, as the materials whereon it is built; and then I promiÅ¿e my Å¿elf this, that though you Å¿hould not like the frame of the building, yet you would not have the Timber loÅ¿t. What I Å¿aw in her LadiÅ¿hip (whom I here preÅ¿ent to your Honour) uÅ¿efull for Å¿uch a work as this, I picked by mine own obÅ¿ervation. Another that could have built this Monument in more Å¿tate, might have found hewn Å¿tones fitted to his hand; though thoÅ¿e, which for their
curious workmanÅ¿hip, I knew not how to place right, are lefr out, not becauÅ¿e I Å¿ee them not, but becauÅ¿e I could not place them to their worth. And having built this Å¿mall Pile of her vertues, not knowing to whom Å¿he more of right belonged then to your Å¿elf, I have made bold to give it your LordÅ¿hips SuperÅ¿cription.

You may Å¿ay to me in this attempt, as Aeneas did to Dido, when Å¿he deÅ¿ired a Narration of the Trojan Wars, Infandumâjubes renovare dolorem; That I bring you again to the houÅ¿e of mouring, and open the Å¿luces of thoÅ¿e eyes that were almoÅ¿t Å¿hut; and for this cauÅ¿e (did I not hope that the profit you may receive, will countervail the Å¿orrow which you will find in the renewing of her remembrance) I Å¿hould have been Å¿ilent: but if the Å¿treams of your teares waÅ¿h your Å¿oul, and your Å¿orrow for her terminate in Å¿orrow for Å¿in, I Å¿hall not think my labour either prepoÅ¿terous, or in vain: if the flood turn inward, I am willing to clenÅ¿e and open, rather then to Å¿top or interrupt the free paÅ¿Å¿age.

When ConÅ¿tantine had Å¿hewn the PerÅ¿ian
King the glory of Rome, and the Å¿tately Monuments of deceaÅ¿ed Emperors, he looked on them, and Å¿aid, Mira quidem haec, Å¿ed ut video, Å¿icut in PerÅ¿ia, Å¿ic Romae, homines moriuntur; though you have men of great renown, yet I Å¿ee as we do in PerÅ¿ia, Å¿o at Rome all dye. I hope your LordÅ¿hip judged Å¿o of her; that though Å¿he was pure, yet Å¿he was brittle; though precious, yet mortal. The Oak in time will decay as well as the Willow; and the Å¿trongeÅ¿t tower, though a Å¿torm will not, yet a thunderclap will Å¿hatter it to pieces: Fragilem frangi, & mortalem mori, to Å¿ee a glaÅ¿s break, or a Candle burn to the Å¿nuff, is no new thing.

It is a mortifying conÅ¿ideration to look over a dead wife, or a dead child; but we who have corruption Å¿o apt to live, had need Å¿ometimes be told that our frame is Å¿ubject to dye: this conÅ¿ideration will Å¿till home-bred Wars, namely, to be told of an invaÅ¿ion; the fleÅ¿h will Å¿ooner be mortified, and the Å¿pirit will endeavour to be Å¿upreme the rather, when it conÅ¿iders that it is accountable.

It was Å¿aid of Alexander, that when he came to Achilles his Tomb, he wept, becauÅ¿e he had not a Homer to Å¿et him forth. For
this purpoÅ¿e it is reported, that AlphonÅ¿us of Arragon, King of Cicily, kept Panormitan the Poet, that he might immortalize his name; and though that cannot be expected from me, what another might have writ, who had known her longer; yet Å¿omething I have obÅ¿erved according to my knowledge; nay, I have Å¿een more in her then I know how to expreÅ¿s here: For he had need be a neat Limner that draws a beauty to the life; and he had need underÅ¿tand the tongue, that attempts to expreÅ¿s her language, and Å¿tands need to have trod in her Å¿teps too, that goeth about to deÅ¿cribe them.

When I conÅ¿idered the remarkableneÅ¿s of the providence, the noiÅ¿e that it made, and how loud it Å¿poke to us all, I thought, God would not have it forgot: and when I conÅ¿idered that in Å¿o Å¿hort a time, the memory of that great Å¿troke was Å¿omething more dark, and ready to wear out, I undertook this work, which I formerly did not intend; namely, to build a Monument, whereby The mother and the Å¿on both dying in a fort-nights Å¿pace. their names, whoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons the Lord hath taken to himÅ¿elf, Å¿hould not be forgotten; and it is becauÅ¿e we have almoÅ¿t forgot to read my Ladies vertues,
that I put them in print; had our memories been better to have retained more, I Å¿hould have Å¿poken leÅ¿s, if any thing at all.

It Å¿eems God Å¿aw that we had need of Å¿uch a great affliction, or elÅ¿e he would not have doubled it; and if the Å¿mart of it do not make impreÅ¿Å¿ion, he can plat another cord, and be more Å¿evere: Oh therefore that what we have felt, might make us Å¿ay, Spare Lord, and we will do Å¿o no more. Could we but find the pleaÅ¿ures of Å¿in to countervail the torment for Å¿in, we might be leÅ¿s cautious: and if it were Å¿o, that brethren in iniquity who have drawn us to Å¿in, could get as much favour hereafter as they get us affliction and Å¿orrow here, we need not be much circumÅ¿pect: but to conÅ¿ider that our very companions, nay, our very Tempters will be our accuÅ¿ers; and he, for whoÅ¿e Å¿ake we became tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ors, will betray us: Surely it is more rational to truÅ¿t God in a way of holineÅ¿s, who will never forÅ¿ake us, then man in a way of Å¿in who will not aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t us in time of danger.

As to my Å¿elf and preÅ¿ent work, it is my firÅ¿t fruits, which had not been ripe yet, but that it was Å¿o Å¿oon Autumn with her; and becauÅ¿e it grows in your LordÅ¿hips Å¿oil, I cannot but dedicate it to your Å¿elf; wherein I do not deÅ¿ire to be Theologus gloriae, but Crucis: As I dare not be found Å¿inning, Å¿o I would not be found idle when my Saviour comes. Perhaps Å¿ome who loved her not, will cenÅ¿ure me for what I have Å¿aid; and thoÅ¿e that deÅ¿ired her vvorth Å¿hould be blotted out, vvill be angry becauÅ¿e I have put it in print; yet this is my comfort, Non ignota
cano; innumeros prompÅ¿it Britannia teÅ¿tes: her light was not laid under a buÅ¿hel; thoÅ¿e that did not Å¿hut their eyes, might have Å¿een as much as I have Å¿poken; theÅ¿e who knew her would have believed themÅ¿elves, though I had not Å¿poken: and thoÅ¿e that did not know her, I could deÅ¿ire them to believe me, except they would have me to diÅ¿truÅ¿t them, when they Å¿peak truth. And if I be cenÅ¿ured, it is no more then I would freely undergo, rather then her dear name Å¿hould be forgot. ThoÅ¿e that will Å¿peak evil, perhaps may have Å¿ome come after them, that will do as much for them. Valla condemned all that writ before him; (which could not be wiÅ¿dome, except he had been Å¿ure to have been the laÅ¿t that had come upon the Å¿tage) EraÅ¿mus comes after, & doth as much for him.

closer.signed: The unworthieÅ¿t, But not the MoÅ¿t faithleÅ¿s Of your LordÅ¿hips Servants, W. F.

Thus we, in Å¿hadowy groves refuÅ¿e our reÅ¿t,
ProÅ¿trate our bodies, Å¿miting on our breaÅ¿t:

Fears pro â¢ reate; one looking on another.
Such th' Ocean in the Å¿eas will Å¿carce Å¿uffice,

Where lies the Å¿inner, even there lies the juÅ¿t:

Let Tragick Elegies here take their turn;

Our earthly orbs Å¿tand Å¿till bereav'd of Å¿enÅ¿e,

O dexterous Å¿oul! O Å¿trange myÅ¿terious skill!
WhoÅ¿e Å¿miles did make alive, whoÅ¿e frowns did kill!
PoiÅ¿onous malice Å¿he could countermand,

Her favours when, and unto whom Å¿he imparts,

WiÅ¿dom, parts, wit, with courteÅ¿ie and love,
Her Jewels were, yet Grace Å¿ate Queen above.
When to the world Å¿he had brought forth her Å¿on,
According to his glaÅ¿s her hours did run:

This Ladies Benjamin, Benoni was. Gen. 35. 18.
Being Å¿et, the night o're Å¿hadowed our hopes;
She was the Sun, and we the Heliotropes.
She was our Center; the eyes of every Å¿oul
Like th' trembling needle, point to her as Pole.
When Planets change their Orbs, when Stars their Sphere,

The Sun will Å¿et, and clouds diÅ¿Å¿olve in tears.

Could I have Å¿acrific'd my life Å¿o dear,

Though Å¿he was Å¿own in tears, Å¿he is reapt in joy.

Her Å¿on with Feaver burnt, the mother would
Become his Urn, his aÅ¿hes for to hold:

So dyed the Phoenix of this Land; yet Å¿he

Though we with grief opprest Å¿hould fall aÅ¿leep,

She reacht to heaven, though on her knees by prayer;

div.head: A SAINTS MONUMENT, OR THE TOMB OF THE Righteous.

epigraph.q: And Sarah dyed in Kiriath-arba; the Å¿ame is Hebron in the Land of Canaan, and Abraham came to mourn for Sarah, and to weep for her.

div.p:
OUR heavenly Father in his great WiÅ¿dom, many times keeps his deareÅ¿t Children Å¿hort in this world: they have famine as well as plenty; tears as well as joy. Cold and NakedneÅ¿s to drive them home to their Fathers houÅ¿e. Prodigal Å¿ons miÅ¿s of their expectation,
or elÅ¿e they would take up lodging with the Å¿wine; Beggars muÅ¿t hunger Å¿ometimes, or elÅ¿e they will not ask; nay, they muÅ¿t be denied, or elÅ¿e they will not be importunate. Thus our holy Father laÅ¿heth his children where he would have them obey, and cauÅ¿eth the Sun to Å¿et, and darkneÅ¿s to overtake them, when he would have them return home: Indeed, the Pinacle of honour in the world is Å¿uch a Å¿lippery place, that when Satan had Å¿et ChriÅ¿t there, he thought he could caÅ¿t him down with more eaÅ¿e, and make his fall the greater; and when he had let him Å¿ee the kingdomes of the earth, he thought he could more eaÅ¿ily keep heaven out of his Å¿ight; when he had given him to know the world, he thought by that means he could Å¿ooneÅ¿t cauÅ¿e him to forget himÅ¿elf; and when he had mounted him Å¿o high, he thought it the only way to make him overlook his own happineÅ¿s. Now if Satan durÅ¿t attempt to aÅ¿Å¿ault the Lord, he is not without Å¿trong hopes of conquering the Servant; therefore leÅ¿t we Å¿hould be oblivious of our frame and nature, our Father gives us a Memorandum; and that we may know our Å¿elves, he lets us Å¿ee our faces in a glaÅ¿s.

Every image of death is but a repreÅ¿entation of our own perÅ¿ons, and tells us who we are. Nothing Å¿ets out man Å¿o much to the life, as the grim viÅ¿age of death. PaleneÅ¿s is the colour wherein man is beÅ¿t limned. Calvin calls Saints Lives, quaÅ¿i Å¿pecula, condimenta, GlaÅ¿Å¿es wherein ChriÅ¿tians may Å¿ee their conÅ¿titutions: the odor that would give a fragrancy to every action. I may call the Saints death GlaÅ¿Å¿es too, wherein we may Å¿ee
our diÅ¿Å¿olution: And indeed if a Saint be but looked through we may Å¿ee from the womb to the grave, from thence to heaven; not not only the mark, but the way is characterized in a Å¿piritual mans life; not only the good beginning, but the happy end in a Å¿piritual mans death. As the informations we have by Saints lives are uÅ¿efull, Å¿o the admonitions we have by their death are needfull. I do not know any that ever lived, but had need be told Å¿ometimes that he muÅ¿t dye: never was there any that became familiar with the fleÅ¿h, but Å¿hould be told he muÅ¿t leave his companion: and there was never any Å¿o unanimouÅ¿ly joyned together, but it was needfull that Å¿ometime he Å¿hould hear of their putting aÅ¿under; for which purpoÅ¿e theÅ¿e words are very uÅ¿efull, for they are the unyoking of an honourable pair, the looÅ¿ing the marriage bonds of the Parents of the faithfull, Abraham and Sarah.

Here you may Å¿ee, though no man may, yet God may put aÅ¿under, what he himÅ¿elf hath joyned together. Abraham took him a wife, Gen. 11. 29. and here God takes her from him, and the more juÅ¿tly, becauÅ¿e Å¿he was his gift. True, HouÅ¿es and Riches are the inheritances of our Fathers, But a prudent wife is of the Lord, Prov. 19. 14. Sarah had Å¿weat at generation work, and God takes her out of the yoke to her reÅ¿t. Sarah was married to the body before Å¿he was marrried to Abraham, which taught her the better to carry her Å¿elf in that Å¿tate: For a birth, or the deÅ¿cent into the body, reÅ¿embles the condition of matrimony: in both they leave their Fathers houÅ¿e, and go into a Å¿trange
land, it was Å¿o with Sarah; The females do not only leave their habitation, but their name; Å¿o in deÅ¿cent into the body; and therefore the Jewes had this Maxime amongÅ¿t them, Matris familia non est familia; they reckoned not their Pedigrees after the mother, but the father, as you may Å¿ee in ChriÅ¿t's! Thus alÅ¿o Abraham when he was married, he muÅ¿t leave his Countrey, and get into a Å¿trange land from his Fathers houÅ¿e, and Fathers kindred, Gen. 12. 1. Sarah had done thus before; Å¿he had, doubtleÅ¿s, better acquaintance above, whom Å¿he left when Å¿he came to be clothed with mortality and with fleÅ¿h; whom, Å¿he in the Text after her long abÅ¿ence, goes to viÅ¿ite; as the opening of the vital powers of the body was the door through which Å¿he enterred into this mortal Å¿tate; (Corporis vita, est mors animae; the life of the body, is the death of the Å¿oul) Å¿o the Å¿huting of thoÅ¿e vital powers of the body, is the door at which the Å¿oul goes out, and that is death.

In the words then we have Sarah's Joy, and Abraham's Å¿orrow, that is Sarah's death, and Abraham's life: What a Å¿trange world is this, that our beÅ¿t friends Å¿hould be the occaÅ¿ion of our greateÅ¿t grief! a low condition of life, when our deareÅ¿t relations are grounds of our bittereÅ¿t tears; when our moÅ¿t choice mercies, put us to the moÅ¿t exquiÅ¿ite pain: We may obÅ¿erve many Doctrines from them, which if I could do any more then mention, might not be without their profit; to name Å¿ome.

There is alÅ¿o a deformity in this uncleanneÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿inners are deformed as well as unclean; all parts unÅ¿hapen, eyes, hands, tongue, feet, heart, head: and look into the Å¿oul, and you Å¿hall find it like the inÅ¿ide of a grave, full of crawling worms, if not Å¿erpents and vipers: as in the body, you would count him a monÅ¿ter where you Å¿ee the foot and head counterchanged, or were the eye upon the forehead, or the eare on the breÅ¿t, we Å¿hould wonder; It is thus with Å¿inners Å¿oules, and with the powers and facultyes thereof; they are all miÅ¿placed; the underÅ¿tanding where ignorance Å¿hould be; the memory, where forgetfullneÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hould be; hope in the place of feare, and joy where we Å¿hould Å¿hew Å¿orrow; deÅ¿ire Å¿et on, that object where loathing and diÅ¿daine Å¿hould be, love where we Å¿hould expreÅ¿Å¿e moÅ¿t hatred, & viÅ¿e verÅ¿a: this being contrary to the true patern of beauty, voluntas Dei, the will of God, it muÅ¿t neceÅ¿sarily follow that men are very deformed, uncae
